The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that are of great interest because of their extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. We report the first genomic and transcriptomic assemblies for two species of myxozoans, and we compare these to the genome and transcriptome of a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, P. hydriforme. We also show that myxozoans have one of the smallest reported animal genomes, and that gene content and expression patterns are highly reduced compared to other cnidarians. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This is a major step forward in our understanding of the evolution of the Myxozoa. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a key factor in their ability to cause disease. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity and that it localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and interacts with Nup98-Rae1. Our results unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect the global food supply, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use a statistical model to project the future variability of maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in most of these countries, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. This instability in global grain trade and international grain prices will affect especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We conclude that investments in breeding for heat tolerance are urgently needed.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that species that are similar in body size and proportional grass consumption have the greatest overlap in diet composition, suggesting that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages. Our results also show that species partition food resources, even when they are similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that plant diversity may be more tightly linked to LMH diversity than is currently recognized. This may have implications for the conservation of LMH in a world of limited resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the U.S. economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, and that the majority of it accumulates in convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. This accumulation is mostly due to the selective removal of millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic by a combination of processes, including nano-fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior, and ballasting. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of floating plastic debris, and of the importance of the selective removal of the larger fragments. It also provides a basis for further research on the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would increase the pressure on ocean resources.

The ability to provide resources to offspring is a defining characteristic of animals and is thought to be a major factor in the evolution of complex social systems. Here, we show that the evolution of social systems has had a strong effect on the reproductive output of animals. We find that the evolution of social systems is associated with increased reproductive output, and that this increase is due to the increased availability of resources to the mother. This result suggests that the evolution of social systems may have been driven by the evolution of the ability to provide resources to offspring. This is a major finding for the evolution of social systems and the evolution of life itself.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising therapeutic approach for MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to detect and respond to a variety of stimuli. The endothelium is able to integrate information from multiple sources and coordinate its responses. This is accomplished by the communication between cells. The nature of the communication network between endothelial cells has been poorly understood. Here, the nature of the communication network between endothelial cells has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The results reveal that the endothelium is a highly connected network with a small-world configuration. The small-world configuration confers particularly dynamic endothelial properties including high signal-propagation speed, stability, and a high degree of synchronizability. These findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This knowledge will be useful for the development of new therapies for vascular diseases.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to provide open access to data that can be used to monitor the pandemic and its impact on society. The API provides data on COVID-19 cases, deaths, and hospitalizations, as well as many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The activation gate is the part of the channel that opens and closes the channel. In this work, we show that the activation gate can allosterically control the shape of the selectivity filter. This allosteric communication is crucial for the proper functioning of the channel.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in human health is still being elucidated, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host and the environment. The gut microbiome is also influenced by the host diet, and the composition of the microbiome can be used as a biomarker for diet and health. The results presented here support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to influence the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. These results have implications for understanding the role of anxiety in social behavior and for the treatment of social disorders.

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses under large deformations is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis approach to design composite structures with multiple material phases to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized with the aid of a digital mock-up, and the corresponding responses are physically realized in experiments. The proposed approach can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. It can also be extended to design structures with complex and navigable responses. This work provides a general strategy for the design of mechanical structures with desired responses. It is expected to inspire the design of mechanical systems with complex and programmable responses.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in mammals. In this study, we demonstrate that a key component of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway, insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1), is expressed in the developing human fetus and is required for the silencing of adult hemoglobin genes. In addition, we show that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of the BCL11A transcription factor, which is required for the expression of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the timing of fetal hemoglobin expression in the placenta and the timing of hemoglobin switching in erythroid cells during development. This may also be relevant to the timing of hemoglobin switching in erythroid cells in hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by SREBP1/SCD1-dependent lipogenesis, and can be overcome by mTORC1 inhibition. In preclinical models, this combination therapy resulted in near-complete tumor regression. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are widely used because of their efficacy and safety. However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling through STIM proteins, which are up-regulated in hypertension. Our findings have implications for the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older forest bird populations, but the recovery of these species has been slow. The NWFP has also failed to halt the decline of early-seral bird populations, which are concentrated in two ecoregions. Our findings underscore the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy presented in this work can be applied to other antibiotic classes. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics to combat antibiotic resistance. Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks can be very large, which can make them difficult to train and apply in practice. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The proposed architecture is based on a simple set of operations that can be easily implemented, trained, and applied in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture can be used in a wide range of problems in computer vision and other fields. It can be used to reduce the number of parameters in existing networks, which can make them easier to train and apply in practice. It can also be used to design new networks that are more efficient in terms of both parameters and computation.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the biological effects of this practice on sleep are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin secretion, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces alertness the following morning. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral immune system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Our results show that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes in their genomes. We propose that these genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDE

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also provide a proof of concept for the application of deep learning in the optimization of other protein molecules. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the evolution of the size of the population than for the evolution of the performance of the artifacts. This is an important finding for evolutionary psychology, as it suggests that the size of the population may be more important for the evolution of the size of the population than for the evolution of the performance of the artifacts. This may have important implications for the evolution of human culture.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE alleles are associated with different rates of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is supported by the recent finding that APOE4 is associated with increased levels of C1q in the brain. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we found that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic (bcc) phase of iron is much more likely to occur than that of the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. They also provide a possible explanation for the origin of the core–mantle boundary anisotropy. (Read more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving.

Language is the only known cognitive skill that evolved in isolation in other species. As such, it is a powerful window into the cognitive and neural mechanisms of the human mind. Here, we use a large-scale, integrative modeling approach to show that the human brain computes language in a highly principled way, with a small number of simple mechanisms that are shared across different datasets and tasks. These results provide computational evidence for the fundamental role of predictive processing in language comprehension, and they suggest that the human language system is a highly efficient and economical model of its natural input.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been unstable, even though it is known that universal approximation theorems guarantee the existence of stable networks. We show that this paradox is due to the fact that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable networks, but there does not exist any algorithm that can compute such a network. This implies a classification theory of conditions under which stable networks can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce a fast iterative restarted network (FIRENET) that we prove is stable and numerically verify is fast and stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. This is the first step toward a theory of stability for DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past epidemics. This is a reference to a classic experiment published in 1972, which demonstrated that people are unable to understand exponential growth. The experiment has been cited in more than 1,000 scientific publications, but its design flaws have been overlooked. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the cause of it has been debated for even longer. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of the causative agent of Hansen's disease, M. leprae. We found that the two pathogens are remarkably conserved, and that the loss of genes in M. lepromatosis is likely to have occurred before the divergence of the two species. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy and may lead to the discovery of new genes that are important for the pathogenesis of leprosy. (Show more)

The dynamics of entanglement in quantum many-body systems is a fundamental question of quantum information theory and statistical mechanics. It is also of great practical relevance, as it determines the speed of decoherence and the rate of approach to equilibrium. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the relevant limit for the study of the evolution of entanglement in quantum computers. We show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the relevant limit for the study of the evolution of entanglement in quantum computers.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives and caused severe economic damage. The only available vaccines are not 100% effective, and the pandemic is far from being over. Therefore, the development of a highly effective vaccine is urgently needed. Here, we describe a vaccine that is highly attenuated and can be manufactured at large scale. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the pandemic.

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks, which has been responsible for high mortality in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). The disease was thought to have been spread by rats during this period, but recent studies have suggested that human ectoparasites, such as fleas, were the primary vectors. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work also provides a framework for studying the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of other diseases.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neuroanatomy. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity has been less studied. This study shows that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is also affected by the evolution of the number of neurons in the brain. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only driven by the evolution of brain size but also by the evolution of the number of neurons. This study has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is controlled by a network of molecular regulators. In this study, we show that a mitochondrial molecular chaperone, TRAP1, regulates the cell cycle and metabolism. This study provides a mechanistic basis for the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers.

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and their disassembly is essential for many cellular processes. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly. However, how it does so remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that mechanical tension has no effect on ADF/cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this ADF/cofilin-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of ADF/cofilin’s action and may lead to the development of new strategies for controlling actin dynamics.

The brain’s reward system is activated by the sight of food, and this activation may contribute to overeating. In this study, we show that the brain’s reward system is activated more strongly by food cues in a fasted relative to a fed state. We also show that ingestion of fructose versus glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that the brain’s reward system may play a role in the differential susceptibility of the obese to food cues and the obese’s preference for sweet foods. This may help explain why some people are more sensitive to the effects of fructose than others. These findings may also lead to the development of new strategies for treating obesity.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. The results suggest that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that the mere observation of others’ negative experiences can lead to the experience of negative emotions. These results have implications for the design of social media platforms, and for our understanding of the role of social media in our lives.

The ribosome is a complex enzyme that can read mRNA sequences in many different ways. One of the most common modifications present in mRNA coding regions is pseudouridine (Ψ), which can have a variety of effects on the ribosome. For example, it can change the rate of translation, the types of amino acids added to a protein, and the rate of protein synthesis. In this study, we show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter all of these outcomes. This suggests that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA and make changes to the rate of translation, the types of amino acids added to a protein, and the rate of protein synthesis. Our work also provides a structural basis for how the presence of Ψ can alter the rate of protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. In this study, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as socioeconomic status, education, and health, and they are maintained over time. These findings suggest that the feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology, but the mechanisms driving the evolution of size in aquatic mammals have not been tested quantitatively. We show that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic medium and is constrained by the energetic demands of feeding and thermoregulation. These constraints lead to a predicted attractor in body size, which is consistent with the observed evolution of body size in aquatic mammals. This work provides a quantitative framework for understanding the evolution of body size in mammals and may have implications for understanding the evolution of body size in other aquatic organisms.

The common cold is the most common disease worldwide, and the virus responsible, rhinovirus, is the most common cause of this disease. The temperature at which rhinovirus replicates most efficiently in the human body is unknown. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the type I IFN response and is abrogated by genetic deficiency of the MAVS protein, which is a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus in the human body. (Show more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of the surface on which it is growing. This sensing mechanism is used to regulate the activity of type IV pili, which in turn promotes the growth of the bacterial biofilm. This is an example of how bacteria can use their motility system to sense the mechanical activity of the surface on which they are growing, and how this sensing system can be used to regulate the bacterial motility and virulence. This work provides insights into the evolution of bacterial sensing systems, and how they can be used to regulate the bacterial motility and virulence. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is the first of its kind to our knowledge. We show that the use of pesticides is widespread and that the risk to aquatic ecosystems is high. This study is important because it provides a quantitative basis for the discussion on the need for improved pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns that the virus could reemerge in a susceptible animal reservoir and continue to circulate in the human population. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a free-living animal species that is susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection. Our findings suggest that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer and that the virus could continue to circulate in the human population through deer-to-deer transmission. These discoveries have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global health crisis. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and tau tangles, but the role of the immune system in AD is not well understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain and that they are responsible for the initiation of an immune response in AD. This finding has implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for understanding the role of this species in the development of agriculture and animal husbandry. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is to be found in the Hellenistic period at the site of Maresha, Israel. The results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a key step in its function. The folding process is a challenge to study because of the large size of the proteins involved. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein of 370 residues. We find that the folding of the protein is a multistep process.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of RNA caps. However, the role of these molecules in the regulation of gene expression is still poorly understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is responsible for the removal of the cap formed by the enzyme NprL, is also able to remove the cap formed by Np4. This enzyme has a unique mechanism for recognizing capped 5′ termini, which positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This could have major consequences for the reprogramming of gene expression during disulfide stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of the disease. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and decreasing the expansion of immunosuppressive cells. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also show that the biomass pyramid of the global marine ecosystem contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They also provide a quantitative basis for understanding the role of the biosphere in the global carbon cycle and the impact of humans on the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system is able to maintain a critical state, despite external perturbations. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, which is the hallmark of criticality. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We describe the connection between our model and pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture toughness. Therefore, it is desirable to control its mechanical properties, such as its elastic modulus and strain at phonon instability. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be fully closed. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be opened, by applying tensile strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This relationship is important for understanding the properties of diamond and for developing diamond-based devices. The findings also provide a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This relationship is important for understanding the properties of diamond and for developing diamond-based devices.

The ability of plants to defend themselves against fungal pathogens is a key factor in the evolution of the plant kingdom. However, the mechanisms of action of many of the plant defense compounds are unknown. Here, we describe the structure of a unique antifungal peptide, the NCR044 peptide, and its mode of action against plant fungal pathogens. The antifungal activity of the peptide is due to its ability to bind to multiple phosphoinositides in germlings, which leads to the disruption of the plasma membrane and subsequent cell death. The mode of action of the peptide is different from that of other known antifungal compounds. This work provides a basis for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This would be a significant contribution to the field of plant disease control.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and the extent of molecular continuity between the sexes is unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract provides a reservoir of proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions and the extent of female contributions to the development of offspring. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease (VWD), a disorder of the blood that causes bleeding. The mechanism also provides a means to study the role of flow in the binding reaction. The results are important for understanding the role of flow in the binding reaction and the role of VWF in the pathogenesis of bleeding. The results also provide a means to study the role of flow in the binding reaction. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses associated with humans, and it is used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and diseases. The results provide a foundation for future studies of the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the ACI process is difficult to be observed simultaneously in space and time. This work introduces a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosols and clouds simultaneously. The instrument is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of the early Earth has been a subject of intense debate. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with NDK thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth's surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They are classified into three types based on their gating mechanism: voltage-gated, ligand-gated, and calcium-gated. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is a calcium-activated potassium channel that lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the gating mechanism of K+ channels. (Show more)

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, with the Plasmodium parasite invading the red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is a complex event, and the role of the host cell in this process has been largely ignored. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC and alters the biophysical properties of the cell, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This would have implications for the development of new antimalarial strategies. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, it is not a perfect insulator, and its electronic bandgap can be modulated by external stimuli. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly under thermal strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a new route to explore the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This work provides a new perspective on the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection and disease severity. Our study may also have implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral therapeutics. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a model of language that is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of a sentence can be described as a sequence of merges, which are operations that combine two words into a phrase. Our results provide initial evidence for the reality of the merge operation and suggest that the brain uses it to build a hierarchy of phrases. This may be a fundamental operation in language processing, and it may be relevant to the development of reading and speech perception.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates, and its regulation is critical for normal development. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its regulation is critical for its function. We show here that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently, and this difference can be used to control the function of the pathway in different tissues. This is a subtle feature that may be important for the control of other redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.

Obesity is a major health concern, and the mechanisms that regulate food intake are not fully understood. Here we describe a circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit is located in the lateral hypothalamus, where it is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area. This circuit is also dependent on noradrenergic neurons in the periaqueductal gray. The circuit is critical for the rapid vigorous eating that occurs after stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus. This circuit may be a target for therapeutic intervention in the treatment of obesity.

Nitrogen is a key nutrient for plant growth and productivity, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is a critical component of sustainable agriculture. In this work, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This system has the potential to provide a sustainable source of nitrogen for cereal crops, and could be used to deliver nitrogen to other crops, such as oilseed rape, that are not suitable for N2-fixing symbiosis. This work also represents a key step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen cycle in agriculture, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen cycle in agriculture.

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to inform forest monitoring and management, but the alerts are often generated too late to deter deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to perceive the world around them. The hearing organs of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are made of cells and are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider’s web is a self-manufactured, protein-based material that is much more sensitive to sound than the spider itself. The spider can hear in all directions, and it can localize the source of the sound. The spider can also hear in silence, and it can hear through noise. The spider’s web is a unique acoustic sensor that can be outsourced to the environment and can be regenerated. This provides a model system for studying acoustic sensing and for designing acoustic sensors with new capabilities. It also provides a new way to hear in silence and in noise. This work provides insights into the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic sensors. It also provides a new way to hear in silence and in noise.

Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. Vaccine development has been accelerated, and several vaccines are now available. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. This study reports the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein, which mediates viral entry to cells. The variant exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, high-yield manufacturability, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. This engineered RBD may be used to design a vaccine or as a component of a vaccine. The engineered VLP may be used to deliver the engineered RBD to the immune system. This work provides a potential solution to the global access of vaccines. (Show more)

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor in infants and children. It is a heterogeneous disease with a high incidence of relapse. In the last years, the role of the ALK receptor tyrosine kinase in neuroblastoma has been investigated. We show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALKALs are able to activate zebrafish Ltk and human ALK, respectively, in vitro. We also show that loss-of-function mutations in zebrafish ALK/Ltk and in human ALKALs cause a complete loss of iridophores, a pigment cell type of neural crest origin. These results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of ALK/Ltk and ALKALs in neural crest development. This is the first report of the involvement of ALK/Ltk in neural crest development.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a key event in the history of the genus Yersinia. However, the number of ancient Y. pestis genomes is too small to explore its diversity during the critical period of its emergence. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which allowed us to explore the temporal, geographical, and genetic diversity of this pathogen during this period. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not highly diverse during this period, and that it underwent a stepwise evolution, possibly leading to its adaptation to fleas. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its ecology. They also reveal the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. These data provide a more complete picture of the history of plague during its formative years.

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands has a large impact on the global carbon cycle. In this study, we show that the management of croplands and grasslands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil. We show that the management of croplands and grasslands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to assess the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans, and created a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results. We used the SpillOver tool to identify 887 wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover to humans. The top 12 were known zoonotic viruses, and several others ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. The SpillOver tool can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work suggests that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is favored by selection and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid with potential pharmaceutical applications. (Show more)

The history of Europe is marked by complex demographic processes, including two major waves of immigration from outside the continent during periods of cultural change. However, the genetic history of the intervening periods has been largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from southern Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men generally closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results provide insights into the history of Europe and the genetic consequences of complex demographic processes. They also demonstrate the power of the genome-wide association study approach to detect signatures of positive selection. Finally, they highlight the potential of ancient DNA to provide insights into the history of Europe.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly emerged pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. The virus is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. Our results suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5 are different, and that the adaptation of MERS-CoV to use human cells for cross-species transmissions is due to the capability of its spike to use human cellular proteases for efficient human cell entry. These results suggest that bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. They also suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are different. Thus, bat coronaviruses may be a potential source of novel coronavirus strains that can cause human diseases.

The ability to rapidly detect and characterize pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We demonstrate the feasibility of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) in a resource-scarce setting to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. We also demonstrate the utility of mNGS in the early detection of chikungunya virus, a disease that is difficult to diagnose in resource-scarce settings. Our findings highlight the potential of mNGS in the detection of undifferentiated febrile illness and the identification of pathogens that are difficult to diagnose in resource-scarce settings.

DNA polymerases are essential enzymes that are responsible for the synthesis of DNA. In humans, the lagging strand synthesis is performed by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). Pol δ is a large enzyme that is composed of a catalytic core and a sliding clamp. The sliding clamp is responsible for the processivity of pol δ and is composed of two subunits, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) and a clamp loader. The clamp loader is responsible for the loading of the sliding clamp onto the polymerase. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that the pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme. This study also provides a foundation for the development of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of human diseases caused by mutations in the pol δ gene.

The origin of life is one of the most fundamental questions in science. The RNA world hypothesis suggests that life may have evolved before the appearance of proteins, and that the genetic material was encoded by RNA. In this paper, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world and the origin of life.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies. However, it is difficult to observe and measure. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. We hope that our work will inspire future research on urban change.

COVID-19 is a severe disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the stage of clinical trial. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody targeting the IL-6 pathways, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a toxic metal that can cause damage to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of isocyanide-derived compounds suggests a role for these compounds in the regulation of copper homeostasis and in the control of interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the control of interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

The origin of silica on Mars is important for understanding the history of the planet and its climate. Silica is a major component of the Martian surface, and its origin and distribution are important for understanding the history of the planet and its climate. Silica is abundant on the surface of Mars, but its origin and distribution are not well understood. Frost damage is a major threat to plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that this change is already affecting the performance of forests. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the ongoing changes in frost frequencies and help forest managers to mitigate the impact of frost damage on trees.

The Th17 cell lineage is central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells and the role of this lineage in the development of colitis are not well understood. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the dual transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells and the support of the development of classic Th1 cells by Th17 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis and suggest that targeting Th17 cells may be a useful therapeutic strategy for the treatment of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is thought to be driven by motor neuron toxicity. However, the mechanisms of motor neuron toxicity are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study the mechanisms of motor neuron toxicity and to screen for therapeutics. This method will enable the study of motor neuron toxicity in a large number of ALS patients and will accelerate the development of ALS therapeutics. This study will also help to understand the role of astrocytes in ALS.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which microbes influence their vector to enhance colonization are poorly understood. Here, we show that a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, modifies the gut microbiota of the tick Ixodes scapularis to more efficiently colonize the vector. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. Birds are one of the most successful groups of animals, and their evolution has been a major topic of research in paleontology. However, the origin of the avian bauplan is still controversial. The climate system is a coupled system, and the climate response to a change in forcing depends on the nature of the forcing. For example, a change in solar radiation does not affect the climate directly, but a change in greenhouse gas forcing does. This study shows that the response of water vapor to a change in temperature also depends on the nature of the change in temperature. This is important to understand because water vapor is the most important greenhouse gas.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the excessive activation of the immune system. The chemical properties of atoms are central to chemistry, and they are also the basis of many chemical models. Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can have significant impacts on the carbon cycle. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the Earth system and the need for improved understanding of the role of human ignitions in shaping future fire regimes.

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly used to understand the world around us. However, the latent patterns in text data are often not fully understood. The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. Language is a complex cognitive ability that is essential for communication and thought. It is also a highly specialized domain, and it is not clear how the brain supports the processing of language. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the ability of neurons to change their firing rates in response to experience. This adaptive change in excitability can be used to store information in the form of dynamic variables that are read back into the membrane potential for processing. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can support the binding of linguistic features over time. Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, leading to conflicting results. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration does not change with experimental warming in most biomes, but that respiration rates with and without experimental warming follow a Gaussian response, increasing with soil temperature up to a threshold of ∼25 °C, above which respiration rates decrease with further increases in temperature. This consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The plastid genome is a unique genetic element that has been shaped by the evolution of the photosynthetic apparatus. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes in the plastid genome, which in turn are linked to the establishment of the parasitic lifestyle. These findings provide insights into the molecular evolution of the plastid genome and its relationship to the evolution of the photosynthetic apparatus. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of South Africa to climate change. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the attribution of the 2015–2017 drought to human influence. However, the results are based on a single model, and further work is needed to confirm the findings.
