This has the potential to contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and to the improvement of population health. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets is a simple and effective way to promote more sustainable diets and healthier eating.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the cell surface proteome is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line expressing oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We also find that the oncogenes depend on the MAPK pathway to propagate signaling, and that this is reflected in the surfaceome of each oncogene. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, there is little evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes. Our results support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface that is not present in SARS-CoV. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2 and may be responsible for the unique immune suppression and evasion activities of this virus. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic induction of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. Furthermore, we show that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into cortical astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. These results provide a molecular understanding of the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. This knowledge may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cerebral edema. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe the problem and its consequences, and illustrate the use of selective inference in some common statistical methods. We also describe some of the recent developments in this area.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of vascular networks. However, the development of vascular ECs has been difficult to achieve in vitro and in vivo. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can induce the development of vascular ECs from fibroblasts. This finding provides a new approach for the development of vascular ECs and the formation of vascular networks. Furthermore, the use of ETV2-expressing cells may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. This study may also provide a new approach for the development of vascular networks in regenerative medicine. (Show more)

The role of RTKs in development and cancer has been extensively studied. However, the physiological function of many RTKs is still unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish augmentor ligands play an important role in pigment development. We also demonstrate that these ligands are essential for zebrafish iridophore patterning and that they are activated by Ltk and not by Alk. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insights into the role of RTKs in development and cancer. It also provides a model system for studying the role of RTKs in zebrafish. This study may also lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases for T2D, the molecular mechanisms underlying these two processes remain to be further elucidated. Herein, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function and is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the transcription factor Pax6 was down-regulated and its nuclear localization was lost in STING-βKO β-cells. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are able to infect a wide range of animal species, which makes them a major threat to human health. The packaging of the viral genome is a key step in the assembly of the viral particles. The influenza A virus genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which favors their co-packaging. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. They also suggest that this interaction could be a target for antiviral drug development. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a multistep process that is initiated by the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in vascular endothelial cells. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the disturbed flow-induced activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in endothelial cells. Our results demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a critical step in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential atherosclerotic lesion formation. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atherogenesis and may lead to the development of a therapeutic strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural and important part of many ecosystems, but they can also be destructive and costly. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity in the United States, but the role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies. However, it is difficult to measure and understand because of the complexity of urban environments. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. We hope that our work will inspire future research on urban change.

Natural repellents are a group of plant-derived compounds that have been used for pest control for thousands of years. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel that mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions toward Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and it should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It also demonstrates the evolutionary adaptation of arthropod–plant interaction. (Show more)

The Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of infection and the dynamics of the disease are not well understood. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid growth of the virus, the short eclipse phase, and the rapid clearance of the virus. We also show that antiviral treatment can be effective in reducing the time to viral clearance. However, the timing of treatment is critical, and treatment initiated too late is mostly ineffective. This work provides a framework for the design of future studies and for the development of antiviral therapies. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of a tumor suppressor gene leads to the activation of a signaling pathway that disrupts the intestinal barrier and alters the composition of the microbiome. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings may have implications for the treatment of intestinal tumors and the restoration of host–microbiome homeostasis. They also provide a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death in women. Chemotherapy is the main treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression was associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is a matter of debate. Here we show that the start of the volcanic eruption record coincides with a unique series of halogen-rich volcanic eruptions, which plausibly led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a poleward shift of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, and thus to the onset of accelerated deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but they are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, our analysis reveals that fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway and is instead triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite. This form of regeneration is reminiscent of a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These connections suggest that the newly discovered DLK-independent regeneration represents a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between this form of regeneration and conditioning, a phenomenon producing robust regeneration in the mammalian CNS. Taken together, our study unites disparate forms of neuronal outgrowth to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. (Show more)

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. In this study, we use a population of wild flowers to map the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no evidence of recombination, and others showing intense activity. The pattern of recombination is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms.

The brain is a highly interconnected network of functionally specialized regions. The study of the functional organization of the brain has been hampered by the lack of a method to identify the main functional networks. Here, we used a nonfluctuating imaging modality, positron emission tomography, to identify and validate the main functional networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant functional network in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant functional network was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. The functional significance of these results is discussed.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. The existence of a 5′ cap in nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast suggests that the 5′ cap is a general feature of eukaryotic mRNA. We show that the 5′ cap in yeast is modified with nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+), a molecule that is involved in a variety of cellular processes. Our results suggest that NAD+ may be involved in the regulation of translation of specific subsets of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes are associated with metabolic memory. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory and provide a basis for further studies to elucidate the mechanisms involved.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and is associated with poor prognosis. In this study, we show that the expression of a cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is associated with poor prognosis in TNBC patients. We further show that FSIP1 is a tumor suppressor and is involved in the regulation of autophagy and AMPK signaling. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 in TNBC and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic, relapsing, and progressive disease, which is characterized by a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with the presence of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) is a key feature of many plant species, and the production of VOCs is a major contributor to the flavor of many fruits. In tomato, the production of VOCs is essential for fruit ripening and the production of a distinctive aroma. However, the production of VOCs is highly variable among species of the tomato clade, and the underlying molecular basis for this variation is unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all VOCs in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the production of a unique class of nitrogenous VOCs. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of VOCs in tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers in the field of plant metabolism. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance curves of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, and suggest that the additional impacts of warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the hippocampus, which is critical for spatial navigation. It is thought that the neurons in MEC form a topographic map of the environment, but the organization of these neurons is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be the main cell type in the map, are anatomically segregated from other cell types. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and will be useful for understanding the function of this region. This work also demonstrates the utility of the portable microscope for neuroscience research. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for flowering of both host and parasite. This finding illustrates the importance of FTs in flowering regulation and the role of FTs in interplant communication. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model system for studying the role of FTs in flowering regulation. (Show more)

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The cause of the disease is unknown, but it is associated with a loss of nigral dopamine-containing neurons and is characterized by motor symptoms. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system within the nigral system that is affected in Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. We show that striatonigral fibers originate from striosome–dendron bouquets, which are specialized integrative units within the nigral system. The striosome–dendron bouquets likely play a role in the control of movement and motivation. Our findings suggest that this system could be a target for therapeutic intervention. This work also provides a model for the study of the organization of the nigro–striato–nigral loop.

We all have a sense of when we are connected to others, but how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that causes the heart to beat. The SAN is a highly specialized cell that is able to adjust its beating rate to meet the demands of the body. In this study, we show that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the size of the Ca2+ stores in the SAN. We also show that STIM1 regulates the electrical activity of the SAN by modulating the activity of a store-operated Ca2+ current. These findings reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the SAN and suggest that STIM1 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmia. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore defense has not been explored. In this study, we demonstrate that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by priming of the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that Si may be used as a tool to enhance plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a complex and dynamic system that is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. The lipid metabolism of macrophages is also affected by the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is a key enzyme in ether lipid metabolism. We show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is a key regulator of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages and that its activity is modulated by tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor that is essential for nitric oxide synthesis. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and suggest that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity affects IFN-γ/lipopolysaccharide signaling.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is essential for communication and thought. It is also a highly specialized domain, and it is not clear how the brain supports the processing of language. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the ability of neurons to change their firing rates in response to experience. This adaptive change in excitability can be used to store information in the form of dynamic variables that are accessed for processing. We show that this mechanism can support memory for short periods of time and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a computational account of language processing that is based on a neurobiological substrate. It may also have implications for other domains of cognitive processing.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic stimuli. Thus, they are dependent on their ability to sense and respond to environmental cues. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the process of sensing and responding to environmental cues. This work demonstrates the delivery of biomolecules to plants and the impact of the geometry of the DNA nanostructure on the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. This work provides a detailed assessment of the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work provides a platform for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and the design of DNA nanostructures for gene silencing in plants. This work also provides a platform for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and the design of DNA nanostructures for gene silencing in plants.

Nutrient loading to lakes and coastal ecosystems is a global problem, driven largely by nonpoint sources from surrounding watersheds. However, most efforts to reduce nutrient loading have focused on large watersheds, ignoring the role of smaller tributaries. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for 70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries exhibit nutrient loads that are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that nutrient inputs from small watersheds may be more important than previously thought in fueling algal blooms in nearshore areas. Our findings highlight the need to expand nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds, which could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a network of chemical reactions in a thermodynamic environment that provides work only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by a small number of large forces, rather than by a large number of small forces. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of synthetic chemical networks that can operate in the presence of thermodynamic forcing. We also discuss the implications of our results for the design of synthetic mechanical systems that can operate in the presence of thermodynamic forcing.

This study offers a mechanistic understanding of the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. We show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes in cortical microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This is a significant advance in our understanding of the mechanisms underlying this condition, which is currently incurable. Our findings also have implications for the treatment of this condition, as we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes in cortical microcircuitry can be reversed by treatment with a drug that blocks the action of NMDAR-Abs. This suggests that the treatment of this condition may be possible in the future.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid warming event, and the history of abrupt warming events is of great interest. However, the history of abrupt warming events is poorly understood because of the lack of data and models that can capture the complexity of the Earth system. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. Our results provide insights into the Earth system response to abrupt warming and may help us understand the current warming. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that the benefits are small and limited to areas that were already deforested before certification. Certification appears to be a tool for reducing deforestation in oil palm plantations, but broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in the evolution of animals, and the sex of an individual can have a major impact on its fitness. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can result in two sexes, or in some cases, more than two sexes. In this study, we investigate the effects of a single genetic locus that determines sex in a group of cichlid fish, where the sex of an individual is determined by two alleles. We find that this system produces a modular set of secondary sexual characteristics, which can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the retina is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species-generating adducts of vitamin A. We sought to understand the role of iron in these processes. We found that iron, as reflected in transferrin receptor mRNA expression, was elevated in retinal pigment epithelial cells in response to oxidative stress. We also found that iron promoted the oxidation and degradation of a bisretinoid, A2E, in the presence of light. These findings suggest that iron may be a key factor in the development of retinal disease. This interpretation is supported by the observation that iron chelation reduced the oxidative/degradation of A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings may lead to the development of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of retinal disease. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is associated with the loss of morphological and functional optimizations. Here we show that specialization can be maintained and even enhanced by the evolution of morphological innovations. This finding has implications for understanding the evolution of biodiversity and the development of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The study of the evolution of the human hand is complicated by the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding is important for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human hand morphology. It also has implications for the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of modern humans. The study also provides a new fossil record for the evolution of the human hand. Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon units are essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2), and have shown that this inhibition blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We have also shown that a deficiency of glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a cancer with a high incidence of poor prognosis. Thus, this work provides a metabolic approach to cancer therapy. The SHMT inhibitor is currently in clinical trials. The glycine import deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can affect people’s diets and that this effect is likely to be negative. This finding has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. Our findings also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries.

Mechanization has been a key driver of agricultural productivity, allowing for the expansion of arable land and food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. This alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the discovery of a 130-m-long, 10-m-wide, and 3-m-deep trackway of a sauropod in the Morrison Formation of Colorado. This trackway provides a unique opportunity to study the effects of large animals on the landscape
